newsitem.title: USA: Dogs' pedigree could be 100,000 years old - study.
newsitem.headline: Dogs' pedigree could be 100,000 years old - study.

text.p: The domestic dog's origins may stretch back far beyond the time when humans became domesticated themselves, possibly as early as 100,000 years ago, researchers reported on Thursday.
Archaeological records suggest that dogs became domesticated about the same time that humans started living in one place and farming, possibly 14,000 years ago.
But a new genetic analysis of dogs and wolves indicates that canines evolved into humans' best friend as a result of a process that may have begun from 60,000 to 100,000 years ago.

"The origin of dogs dates well before the development of agricultural population centres that occurred approximately 10,000-14,000 years ago, and goes back to hunter-gatherer societies," biologist Robert Wayne of the University of California-Los Angeles said in a statement.
To reach their conclusions, Wayne and his colleagues studied DNA -- the basic genetic material -- from 140 dogs representing 67 breeds, from St. Bernards to poodles.
They also analysed DNA from 162 wolves from various countries, as well as the DNA of jackals and coyotes.
The researchers found a surprisingly diverse sampling of DNA, much more than would have been expected if dogs as now known had evolved around 14,000 years ago.
These diverse DNA sequences indicated that the species may have evolved far earlier than suspected, the researchers wrote in this week's edition of the journal Science.

"Given the amount of genetic diversity that we found, we can calculate how long it should have taken to achieve this diversity if mutations alone were driving the process," Wayne said. "Our calculations suggest the first domestic dog might be as old as 100,000 years or older."
The study also found that dogs' closest relatives may be wolves, rather than jackals or coyotes.
Most modern breeds of dogs originated in the last several hundred years due to modern breeding practices, Wayne said.
